input-format.name: input-format
input-format.description:
Specify the input format to be JSON or XML.
It is equivalent to set `Content-Type` header to `application/json` or `application/xml`.
If both `input-format` and `Content-Type` header are presented, the value of `input-format` will override the header.

output-format.name: output-format
output-format.description:
Specify the output format to be JSON or XML.
It is equivalent to set `Accept` header to `application/json` or `application/xml`.
If both `output-format` and `Accept` header are presented, the value of `output-format` will override the header.

basic-auth.description:
To make an API request to the firewall or  Panorama, you must provide an API key to authenticate. For authenticating, you need to:
* Create your admin account on the device.
* Use your admin credentials to get an API key using the keygen command.

Although basic authentication is supported, as a best practice, generate an API key and use it in the authentication
header to make API calls.

tags.name: key-generation
tags.description: To use the API, generate the API key required for authenticating API calls. For instructions, see Get your API key.

tags.name: objects-addresses
tags.description:
Manages address objects that allow you to reuse the same object as a source or destination address across all the policy rulebases
without having to add the address manually each time. An address object is an entity in which you can include IPv4 addresses, IPv6
addresses (a single IP address, a range of addresses, or a subnet) or FQDNs.

tags.name: objects-address-groups
tags.description:
Manages address groups that simplify the creation of policy rules. If you have IP addresses or address objects
that require the same security settings, you can combine them into address groups. An address group can be static or dynamic.
* Dynamic Address Groups: A dynamic address group populates its members dynamically using looks ups for tags and tag-based filters.
Dynamic address groups are very useful if you have an extensive virtual infrastructure where changes in virtual machine
location/IP address are frequent. For example, you have a sophisticated failover setup or provision new virtual machines
frequently and would like to apply policy to traffic from or to the new machine without modifying the configuration/rules
on the firewall.
* Static Address Groups: A static address group can include address objects that are static, dynamic address groups, or it can be a combination of both address objects and dynamic address groups.

tags.name: objects-regions
tags.description:
Manages policy rules that are specific to countries or regions. The region is available as an option when specifying source
and destination for security policies, decryption policies, and DoS policies. Use the APIs described here to manage
custom regions.

tags.name: objects-dynamic-user-groups
tags.description:
Manages dynamic user groups. With dynamic user groups, you can use tags to define groups that automatically contain
users who match the criteria you define. These groups enable you to mitigate risk when the data about a security incident
contains only a username. They also allow you to link users with information from log forwarding and risk assessment
applications, providing a more complete view of user behavior than you would see with user directories alone.

tags.name: objects-applications
tags.description:
Manages application definitions. Each definition includes the application's security risk (1 to 5). The risk value
is based on criteria such as whether the application can share files, is prone to misuse, or tries to evade
firewalls. Higher values indicate higher risk.

Application definitions are used by next-generation firewalls to enable or disable application network activity.

tags.name: objects-application-groups
tags.description:
Manages application groups. To simplify creation of security policies, applications can be combined
into groups. Each application is added to a group using its name.

tags.name: objects-application-filters
tags.description:
Manages application filters, which are used to create security policies based on application characteristics.
For example, a filter could match based on Category "business-systems" and Subcategory "office-programs".
Network access by any application with those two characteristics (such as Google Docs or Microsoft Office 365)
can then be enabled or disabled using a security policy defined by the filter. Future applications that match
the filter will also be automatically be managed by the filter-based security policy.

tags.name: objects-services
tags.description:
Manages service objects, which are used to identify network services that applications can or can not use.
Network services can be defined based on protocols and/or ports. You can also use service objects
to define session timeout values.

tags.name: objects-service-groups
tags.description:
Manages service groups. To simplify creation of security policies, service objects can be grouped.
Add service objects to a group using the object's name.

tags.name: objects-tags
tags.description:
Manages tags, which are keywords and colors that can be assigned to address objects, address groups
(static and dynamic), zones, services, service groups, and policy rules. Tags can be used on the
next-generation firewall to sort or filter objects.

tags.name: objects-global-protect-hip-objects
tags.description:
Manages HIP objects that serve as the building blocks for creating HIP profiles which
you can attach to Security policy rules.  HIP objects provide the match criteria for filtering the raw data reported by
an agent or app that you want to use to enforce policy. Keep HIP objects simple and match on one thing such as the presence
of a particular type of required software, membership in a specific domain, or the presence of a specific client OS.

tags.name: objects-global-protect-hip-profiles
tags.description:
Manages HIP profiles which are a collection of HIP objects. A HIP profile is a collection of HIP objects that are evaluated together
either for monitoring or for security policy enforcement. Using HIP for policy enforcement allows you to ensure
that the hosts and endpoints accessing your critical resources are adequately maintained and in adherence with your security standards
before they are allowed access to your network resources.

tags.name: objects-external-dynamic-lists
tags.description:
Manages external dynamic lists. An external dynamic list  is an address object based on an
imported list of IP addresses, URLs, or domain names that you can use
in policy rules to block or allow traffic. This list must be a text file
saved to a web server that is accessible by the firewall. The firewall
uses the management (MGT) interface by default to retrieve this list.

tags.name: objects-custom-data-patterns
tags.description:
Manages custom data patterns that enable you to filter for sensitive information. Custom data patterns enable you to match on sensitive contents
or specific metadata in a file. You can select from a predefined list of patterns, specify regular expressions, or select the file properties
that you want to match on and enforce Data Filtering policies.

tags.name: objects-custom-spyware-signatures
tags.description: Manages custom spyware signatures used to identify spyware phone home communication. You can create custom signatures by combining the signatures available on the firewall to create custom match conditions or write custom regular expression patterns to identify spyware phone home communication or vulnerability exploits. Content updates periodically include new decoders and contexts to help you develop custom signatures. When you add the signature as a rule in an Anti-Spyware profile, and then attach the Anti-Spyware profile to a Security policy rule, the firewall looks for the custom-defined patterns in network traffic and takes the specified action.

tags.name: objects-custom-vulnerability-signatures
tags.description: Manages custom vulnerability signatures used to identify vulnerability exploits. You can create custom signatures by combining the signatures available on the firewall to create custom match conditions or write custom regular expression patterns to identify spyware phone home communication or vulnerability exploits. Content updates periodically include new decoders and contexts to help you develop custom signatures. When you add the signature as a rule in an Vulnerability Protection profile, and then attach the Vulnerability Protection profile to a Security policy rule, the firewall looks for the custom-defined patterns in network traffic and takes the specified action.

tags.name: objects-custom-url-categories
tags.description:
Manages custom URL categories. Use custom URL categories to create a custom list of URLs and use it in a URL filtering profile or as
match criteria in policy rules. In a custom URL category, you can add URL entries individually, or import a text file that contains a list of URLs.

tags.name: objects-antivirus-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Antivirus security profiles used to block known malicious files (malware, ransomware bots, and viruses)
as they are coming into the network. The Antivirus profile has decoders that detect and prevent viruses
and malware from being transferred over six protocols: HTTP, SMTP, IMAP, POP3, FTP, or SMB.
You can set WildFire actions for all six protocols because the Antivirus profile also enforces actions
based on WildFire signatures.

tags.name: objects-anti-spyware-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Anti-Spyware security profiles used to detect command-and-control traffic (C2) initiated from malicious code running
on a server or endpoint and prevent compromised systems from establishing an outbound connection from your network.

You can also use the Anti-Spyware profile to the profile to enable DNS sinkhole and packet capture to help you track
down any endpoints attempting to resolve malicious domains.

tags.name: objects-vulnerability-protection-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Vulnerability Protection security profiles used to protect against buffer overflows, illegal code execution, and other
attempts to exploit client- and server-side vulnerabilities.

tags.name: objects-url-filtering-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages URL Filtering security profiles used to control access to web content based on URL category as well as to
detect and prevent users from submitting credentials to web sites.

tags.name: objects-file-blocking-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages File Blocking security profiles used to block users from uploading or downloading specified file types
or to generate an alert when a user attempts to upload or download specified file types.

You can define your own custom File Blocking profiles, or choose one of the following predefined profiles when
applying file blocking to a Security policy rule. The predefined profiles allow you to quickly enable best practice
file blocking settings:

* **basic file blocking**Blocks files that are commonly included in malware attack campaigns or that have no real use case for upload/download.
* **strict file blocking**Blocks the same file types as the other profile, and additionally blocks flash, .tar, multi-level encoding, .cab, .msi,
encrypted-rar, and encrypted-zip files.

tags.name: objects-wildfire-analysis-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages WildFire Analysis security profiles used to specify what files the firewall should forward to WildFire for analysis based on application,
file type, and transmission direction (upload or download).

tags.name: objects-data-filtering-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Data Filtering security profiles used to prevent sensitive informationsuch as credit card or social security numbersfrom leaving the
protected network. This profile also allows filtering on key words, such as a sensitive project name or the word "confidential".

tags.name: objects-dos-protection-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages DoS Protection security profiles used to protect against new session IP flood attacks and provide resource protection (maximum concurrent
session limits for specified endpoints and resources). DoS Protection profiles protect specific devices (classified profiles) and groups
 of devices (aggregate profiles) against SYN, UDP, ICMP, ICMPv6, and other IP flood attacks.

tags.name: objects-gtp-protection-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages GTP Protection security profiles used to inspect GTP traffic on firewalls with GTP Security enabled. The options in this profile
enable stateful inspection of GTP v1-C, GTP v2-C, and GTP-U, enable protocol validation for GTPv1-C, GTP v2-C and GTP-U, enable GTP-U content
inspection to scan user data within GTP-U tunnels. It also allows you to filter GTP sessions based on APN, IMSI-Prefix, and RAT, and prevent
end-user IP address spoofing to protect the mobile subscribers from being overbilled.

tags.name: objects-sctp-protection-security-profiles
tags.description:
Manages SCTP Protection security profiles used to validate and filter SCTP chunks on firewalls with SCTP Security enabled. An SCTP packet includes
a common SCTP header and a variable number of chunks, which can be control chunks or data chunks with encapsulated user data.

The firewall provides a multilayered approach for securing SCTP traffic, enabling validation of SCTP packets to ensure they comply with RFC 4960, filtering
of SCTP traffic based on payload protocol IDs (PPIDs), and granular-level filtering on Diameter traffic over SCTP and SS7
traffic over SCTP. You can also protect against flooding of SCTP initiation (INIT) packets. In the case of mobile networks, these security measures
prevent attackers from causing network congestion and outages that disrupt data and voice services of mobile subscribers and IoT devices connected to
these networks. Additionally, you can view SCTP logs, ACC information, and reports to verify configurations and gain visibility into the SCTP events
and traffic between two endpoints.

tags.name: objects-security-profile-groups
tags.description:
Manages Security Profile groups, which is a set of security profiles that can be treated as a unit and then easily added to security policy rules.
Profiles that are often assigned together can be added to  a security profile group to simplify the creation of security policy rules.

Naming a security profile group *default" triggers the firewall to attach the profile to all new security policy rules, further simplifying security policy
management.

tags.name: objects-authentications
tags.description:
Manages authentication enforcement objects that specifies the method and service to use for authenticating end users who access your network resources.
You assign the object to Authentication policy rules, which invoke the authentication method and service when traffic matches a rule.

The firewall has the following predefined, read-only authentication objects
* default-browser-challengeThe firewall transparently obtains user authentication credentials.
  If you select this action, you must enable Kerberos Single Sign-On (SSO) or NT LAN Manager (NTLM) authentication when you configure Captive Portal.
  If Kerberos SSO authentication fails, the firewall falls back to NTLM authentication.
  If you did not configure NTLM, or NTLM authentication fails, the firewall falls back to the authentication method specified in the predefined default-web-form object.
* default-web-form To authenticate users, the firewall uses the certificate profile or authentication profile you specified
  when configuring Captive Portal. If you specified an authentication profile, the firewall ignores any Kerberos SSO settings in the
  profile and presents a Captive Portal page for the user to enter authentication credentials.
* default-no-captive-portalThe firewall evaluates Security policy without authenticating users.

Before creating a custom authentication enforcement object, you must configure a server profile that specifies how to connect to the
authentication service (Device > Server Profiles). Then, assign the server profile to an authentication profile that specifies authentication settings such as
Kerberos single sign-on parameters (Device > Authentication Profile).

tags.name: objects-decryption-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Decryption profiles which enable you to block and control specific aspects of SSL and SSH traffic that you have specified for decryption,
as well as traffic that you have explicitly excluded from decryption.
To enable a decryption profile, you can add the profile to a decryption policy; any traffic that matches the decryption policy is
additionally enforced based on the profile settings.

tags.name: objects-packet-broker-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Packet Broker profiles that enable the firewall to act as a Network Packet Broker. A Network Packet Broker firewall forwards
traffic that it has inspected to a security chain  a set of inline, third-party security appliancesfor additional enforcement.
When the firewall receives traffic back from the security chain, it forwards the traffic to the appropriate destination.

Before you create a Network Packet Broker profile, you must:
* Enable SSL Forward Proxy decryption.
* Activate the free Network Packet Broker license.
* Dedicate at least two Layer 3 interfaces on the firewall for forwarding decrypted traffic to the security chain (Network> Interfaces > Ethernet)
After you complete these tasks, create a Network Packet profile to pair the two interfaces and define settings for the security chain to which
the firewall will forward traffic.

tags.name: objects-sdwan-path-quality-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Path Quality profiles, which define the maximum path health thresholds an application can withstand before it is necessary to fail over to
a healthier path. Path Quality profiles include maximum jitter, latency, and packet loss thresholds.

tags.name: objects-sdwan-saas-quality-profiles
tags.description:
Manages SaaS quality profile in either Adaptive, Static IP Address, or HTTP/HTTPS mode. This monitors the health between an SD-WAN branch and SaaS or cloud application.
You can reference the profile in an SD-WAN policy rule.

tags.name: objects-sdwan-traffic-distribution-profiles
tags.description:
Manages SD-WAN Traffic Distribution profiles, which specify how the firewall determines a new best path if the current preferred path fails
a path quality requirement. An SD-WAN Traffic Distribution profile includes Link Tags, which the distribution method uses to narrow its
selection of a new path.

tags.name: objects-sdwan-error-correction-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Error Creation profiles using either Forward Error Connection or Packet Duplication. This enables you to set standards for packet loss conditions that trigger
either Forward Error Correction or Packet Duplication so you can have better assurances for traffic like voice and video.

tags.name: objects-schedules
tags.description:
Manages the time period for which a rule is active. For each schedule, you can specify a fixed date and time range
or a recurring daily or weekly schedule and then attach it to Security policy rules, QoS rules, or DoS rules.

By default, Security policy rules are always in effect (all dates and times). To limit a Security policy rule to a specific time period,
you can define a schedule and then apply it to the policy rule.

tags.name: policies-security-pre-rules
tags.description:
Security policy rules reference security zones and enable you to allow, restrict, and track traffic on your network based on the application,
user or user group, and service (port and protocol). By default, the firewall includes a security rule named rule1 that allows all traffic from
the Trust zone to the Untrust zone. When you add a pre rule and push it to the managed firewall from Panorama, the pre rule is added to the top
of the rule order and is evaluated before the local firewall rule1.

tags.name: policies-security-post-rules
tags.description:
Security policy rules reference security zones and enable you to allow, restrict, and track traffic on your network based on the application,
 user or user group, and service (port and protocol). By default, the firewall includes a security rule named rule1 that allows all traffic from
 the Trust zone to the Untrust zone. When you add a post rule and push it to the managed firewall from Panorama, the post rule is added to the bottom
of the rule order and is evaluated after the local firewall rule1.

tags.name: policies-nat-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Network Address Translation (NAT) policy rules. These rules specify whether source or destination IP addresses and ports
are converted between public and private addresses and ports.

NAT rules are based on source and destination zones, source and destination addresses, and application service (such as HTTP).
Like security policies, NAT policy rules are compared sequentially against incoming traffic; the first rule that matches
the traffic is applied.

tags.name: policies-nat-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Network Address Translation (NAT) policy rules. These rules specify whether source or destination IP addresses and ports
are converted between public and private addresses and ports.

NAT rules are based on source and destination zones, source and destination addresses, and application service (such as HTTP).
Like security policies, NAT policy rules are compared sequentially against incoming traffic; the first rule that matches
the traffic is applied.

tags.name: policies-qos-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Quality of Service (QoS) rules. These rules define the traffic that receives QoS treatment. Each
rule also identifies a Quality of Service class (numbered 1 - 8) using the `action` field in the
rule payload. QoS classes are defined on the firewall using QoS Policy rules.

tags.name: policies-qos-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Quality of Service (QoS) rules. These rules define the traffic that receives QoS treatment. Each
rule also identifies a Quality of Service class (numbered 1 - 8) using the `action` field in the
rule payload. QoS classes are defined on the firewall using QoS Policy rules.

tags.name: policies-policy-based-forwarding-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Policy-Based Forwarding (PBF) rules. A PBF rule allows you to direct traffic to a specific egress interface
on the firewall and override the default path for the traffic.

When creating a PBF rule, you must specify a name for the rule, a source zone or interface, and an egress interface.

tags.name: policies-policy-based-forwarding-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Policy-Based Forwarding (PBF) rules. A PBF rule allows you to direct traffic to a specific egress interface
on the firewall and override the default path for the traffic.

When creating a PBF rule, you must specify a name for the rule, a source zone or interface, and an egress interface.

tags.name: policies-decryption-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Decryption rules that allow the firewall to decrypt, inspect, and control inbound and outbound SSL and SSH connections.

In a Decryption policy you can specify what you want to traffic to decrypt by destination, source, service, or URL category,
and whether to block, restrict, or forward the traffic according to the security settings in the associated Decryption profile.

tags.name: policies-decryption-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Decryption rules that allow the firewall to decrypt, inspect, and control inbound and outbound SSL and SSH connections.

In a Decryption policy you can specify what you want to traffic to decrypt by destination, source, service, or URL category,
and whether to block, restrict, or forward the traffic according to the security settings in the associated Decryption profile.

tags.name: policies-network-packet-broker-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages policy rules that allow the firewall to decrypt, inspect, and control inbound and outbound SSL and SSH connections as well as
plain text traffic. In a Network Packet Broker rule you can specify when to send traffic to this rule by destination, source, service, or URL category,
and whether to block, restrict, or forward the traffic according to the security settings in the associated Packet Broker profile.

tags.name: policies-network-packet-broker-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages policy rules that allow the firewall to decrypt, inspect, and control inbound and outbound SSL and SSH connections as well as
plain text traffic. In a Network Packet Broker rule you can specify when to send traffic to this rule by destination, source, service, or URL category,
and whether to block, restrict, or forward the traffic according to the security settings in the associated Packet Broker profile.

tags.name: policies-tunnel-inspection-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Tunnel Inspection rules. Tunnel inspection rules allow you to match an incoming packet and specify the
tunnel protocols--GRE, non-encrypted IPSec, GTP-U, or VXLAN -- for which the firewall will inspect content and the conditions under
which the firewall drops or continues to process the packet.

tags.name: policies-tunnel-inspection-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Tunnel Inspection rules. Tunnel inspection rules allow you to match an incoming packet and specify the
tunnel protocols--GRE, non-encrypted IPSec, GTP-U, or VXLAN -- for which the firewall will inspect content and the conditions under
which the firewall drops or continues to process the packet.

tags.name: policies-application-override-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages application override rules. An application override rule allows you to define how the firewall identifies traffic for a custom
application on your network using the application-specific definition that include the zone, source and destination address, port, and protocol.

tags.name: policies-application-override-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages application override rules. An application override rule allows you to define how the firewall identifies traffic for a custom
application on your network using the application-specific definition that include the zone, source and destination address, port, and protocol.

tags.name: policies-authentication-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Authentication rules that enable you to successfully authenticate an end user before he/she can access services and applications.
To authenticate users, you can define one or more methods (factors), such as login and password, Voice, SMS, Push, or One-time Password (OTP) authentication.

tags.name: policies-authentication-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Authentication rules that enable you to successfully authenticate an end user before he/she can access services and applications.
To authenticate users, you can define one or more methods (factors), such as login and password, Voice, SMS, Push, or One-time Password (OTP) authentication.

tags.name: policies-dos-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages Denial of Service (DoS) rules. To protect your endpoints and resources in each security zone against
DoS attacks, these rules allow you to protect, deny, or allow packets that match a source interface, zone, address or user,
and/or a destination interface, zone, or user.

DoS Protection Profiles and policy rules work together to provide protection against flooding of many incoming SYN, UDP, ICMP,
and ICMPv6 packets, and other types of IP packets. A DoS Protection policy rule that is set to protect (rather than to allow or
deny packets) determines the criteria for packets to match (such as source address) in order to count toward the thresholds you
have defined in a DoS Protection Profile.

tags.name: policies-dos-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages Denial of Service (DoS) rules. To protect your endpoints and resources in each security zone against
DoS attacks, these rules allow you to protect, deny, or allow packets that match a source interface, zone, address or user,
and/or a destination interface, zone, or user.

DoS Protection Profiles and policy rules work together to provide protection against flooding of many incoming SYN, UDP, ICMP,
and ICMPv6 packets, and other types of IP packets. A DoS Protection policy rule that is set to protect (rather than to allow or
deny packets) determines the criteria for packets to match (such as source address) in order to count toward the thresholds you
have defined in a DoS Protection Profile.

tags.name: policies-sdwan-pre-rules
tags.description:
Manages SD-WAN policy rules. An SD-WAN policy rule enables you to control when and how the firewall
performs application-based SD-WAN path selection for a packet not belonging to a session. An SD-WAN policy
rule uses application(s) and/or service(s), a Path Quality profile, and a Traffic Distribution profile
to determine how the firewall selects the preferred path for an incoming packet that doesnt belong to
an existing session and that meets its match criteria. When you add a pre rule and push it to the managed
firewall from Panorama, the pre rule is added to the top of the rule order.

tags.name: policies-sdwan-post-rules
tags.description:
Manages SD-WAN policy rules. An SD-WAN policy rule enables you to control when and how the firewall performs
application-based SD-WAN path selection for a packet not belonging to a session. An SD-WAN policy rule uses
application(s) and/or service(s), a Path Quality profile, and a Traffic Distribution profile to determine how
the firewall selects the preferred path for an incoming packet that doesnt belong to an existing session
and that meets its match criteria. When you add a post rule and push it to the managed firewall from Panorama,
the post rule is added to the bottom of the rule order.

tags.name: network-aggregate-ethernet-interfaces
tags.description:
Manages Aggregate Ethernet interface groups, which use IEEE 802.1AX link aggregation to combine multiple
Ethernet interfaces into a single virtual interface that connects the firewall to another network
device or another firewall.

tags.name: network-vlan-interfaces
tags.description:
Manages VLAN interfaces, which can provide routing into a Layer 3 network (IPv4 and IPv6). You can add
one or more Layer 2 Ethernet ports to a VLAN interface.

tags.name: network-loopback-interfaces
tags.description: Manages loopback interfaces on the firewall.

tags.name: network-tunnel-interfaces
tags.description:
Manages tunnel interfaces. To set up a VPN tunnel, the Layer 3 interface at each end must have a
logical tunnel interface for the firewall to connect to and establish a VPN tunnel. A tunnel
interface is a logical (virtual) interface that is used to deliver traffic between two endpoints.

tags.name: network-sdwan-interfaces
tags.description:
Manages virtual SD-WAN interfaces. A virtual SD-WAN interface is a VPN or DIA group of one or more interfaces that
constitute a numbered, virtual SD-WAN Interface to which you can route traffic. The paths belonging to the SD-WAN Interface
all go to the same destination WAN.

tags.name: network-zones
tags.description:
Manages security zones, which are a logical way to group physical and virtual interfaces on the
firewall to control and log the traffic that traverses specific interfaces on your network.

tags.name: network-vlans
tags.description:
Manages VLANs. The firewall supports VLANs that conform to the IEEE 802.1Q standard. Each
Layer 2 interface defined on the firewall can be associated with a VLAN. The same VLAN can be
assigned to multiple Layer 2 interfaces but each interface can belong to only one VLAN.

tags.name: network-virtual-wires
tags.description:
Manages virtual wires. A virtual wire logically binds two Ethernet interfaces together, allowing
for all traffic to pass between the interfaces, or just traffic with selected VLAN tags (no
other switching or routing services are available).

tags.name: network-virtual-routers
tags.description:
Manages virtual routers. The firewall requires a virtual router to obtain routes to other subnets
either using static routes that you manually define, or through participation in Layer 3 routing
protocols (dynamic routes).

tags.name: network-ipsec-tunnels
tags.description:
Manages IPSec tunnel configurations, which allow you to authenticate and/or encrypt
the data (IP packets) as they traverse across the tunnel.

tags.name: network-gre-tunnels
tags.description:
Manages Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnels. The GRE tunnel protocol is a carrier protocol that
encapsulates a payload protocol. The GRE packet itself is encapsulated in a transport
protocol (IPv4 or IPv6). The GRE tunnel connects two endpoints in a point-to-point, logical link between
the firewall and a router (or another firewall).

tags.name: network-dhcp-servers
tags.description:
Manages interfaces acting as DHCP servers. The interface of a DHCP server or relay agent
must be a Layer 3 Ethernet, Aggregated Ethernet, or Layer 3 VLAN interface.

tags.name: network-dhcp-relays
tags.description:
Manages interfaces acting as DHCP relay agents. DHCP relay agents enable a firewall interface to transmit
DHCP messages between clients and servers. Before configuring a firewall interface as a DHCP relay agent,
make sure you have configured a Layer 3 Ethernet or Layer 3 VLAN interface and that you assigned the
interface to a virtual router and a zone.

tags.name: network-dns-proxies
tags.description:
Manages the DNS proxy objects, which enable you to configure settings that determine how a firewall
functions as a DNS proxy. When configured as a DNS proxy, the firewall is an intermediary between
DNS clients and servers.

tags.name: network-gp-portals
tags.description:
Sets up and manages a GlobalProtect portal. The portal provides the management functions for the
GlobalProtect infrastructure. Every endpoint that participates in the GlobalProtect network receives
its configuration from the portal, including information about the
available gateways and any client certificates that are necessary for the app to connect to a gateway.
You must use a unique name for each GlobalProtect Portal you create regardless of location.

tags.name: network-gp-gateways
tags.description:
Manages GlobalProtect gateways, which provide security enforcement for traffic from GlobalProtect apps.
If the HIP feature is enabled, the gateway generates a HIP report from the raw host data the apps submit
and can use this information in policy enforcement. You can configure different types of gateways to
provide security enforcement and/or virtual private network (VPN) access for your remote users, or to
apply security policy for access to internal resources.

tags.name: network-gp-gateway-agent-tunnels
tags.description:
Enables tunneling and configures GlobalProtect agent tunnel parameters.
Tunnel parameters are required for an external gateway and optional for an internal gateway.

tags.name: network-gp-gateway-satellite-tunnels
tags.description:
Manages GlobalProtect satellite tunnel configuration. A satellite is a Palo Alto Networks
firewall, typically at a branch office, that acts as a GlobalProtect app to enable it to
establish VPN connectivity to a GlobalProtect gateway.

tags.name: network-gp-mdm-servers
tags.description:
Manages the MDM integration service that performs a full HIP query to the AirWatch MDM server to retrieve
the complete host information for a mobile device.

tags.name: network-gp-clientless-apps
tags.description:
Manages a list applications that are accessible through the GlobalProtect Clientless VPN. GlobalProtect
Clientless VPN provides secure remote access to common enterprise web applications that use HTML, HTML5,
and JavaScript technologies. Users have the advantage of secure access from SSL-enabled web browsers
without installing GlobalProtect software.

tags.name: network-gp-clientless-app-groups
tags.description:
Enables you to group applications that are accessible through the GlobalProtect Clientless VPN.
Groups are useful for working with multiple clientless applications at the same time.

tags.name: network-qos-interfaces
tags.description:
Manages Quality of Service (QoS) interface settings. Enable QoS on an interface to set bandwidth
limits for the interface and/or to enable the interface to enforce QoS for egress traffic.

tags.name: network-lldp
tags.description:
Manages the firewall Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP), which provides an automatic method of discovering
neighboring devices and their capabilities at the Link Layer.

tags.name: network-gp-ipsec-crypto-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages GlobalProtect IPSec Crypto Profiles, which have algorithms for authentication and
encryption in VPN tunnels between a GlobalProtect gateway and clients.

tags.name: network-ike-gateway-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Gateway network profiles, which specify the
configuration information necessary to perform IKE protocol negotiation with a peer gateway.
This is the Phase 1 portion of the IKE/IPSec VPN setup.

tags.name: network-ike-crypto-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Crypto Profiles, which specify protocols and algorithms for identification, authentication, and
encryption (IKEv1 or IKEv2, Phase 1).

tags.name: network-ipsec-crypto-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages IPSec Network Cryptography profiles that specify protocols and algorithms for authentication and encryption in VPN tunnels based
on IPSec SA negotiation.

tags.name: network-tunnel-monitor-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages tunnel monitoring profiles. A tunnel monitoring profile allows you to verify connectivity
between the VPN peers; you can configure the tunnel interface to ping a destination IP address
at a specified interval and specify the action if the communication across the tunnel is broken.

tags.name: network-interface-management-network-profiles
tags.description:
Managers Interface Management profiles, which protect the firewall from unauthorized access
by defining the services and IP addresses that a firewall interface permits.

tags.name: network-zone-protection-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Zone Protection network profiles. A Zone Protection profile applied to a zone offers
protection against most common floods, reconnaissance attacks, other packet-based attacks,
and the use of non-IP protocols. It is designed to provide broad-based protection at the
ingress zone (the zone where traffic enters the firewall) and is not designed to protect
a specific end host or traffic going to a particular destination zone.

tags.name: network-qos-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Quality of Service (QoS) profiles, each of which defines the bandwidth limits and priority for up
to eight classes of service.

tags.name: network-lldp-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Linked Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) profiles, which allow you to configure the LLDP mode
of a firewall, enable syslog and SNMP notifications, and configure the optional Type-Length-Values
(TLVs) you want transmitted to LLDP peers.

tags.name: network-bfd-network-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD). BFD is a protocol that enables extremely fast detection of
a link failure, which accelerates failover to a different route.

tags.name: network-sdwan-interface-profiles
tags.description:
Manages SD-WAN Interface profiles.  An SD-WAN Interface profile groups physical links by Link Tag and controls
the speed of links and how frequently the firewall monitors the link. Each profile specifies the Tag that you
apply to the physical interface and also specifies the type of Link that interface is (ADSL/DSL, cable modem,
Ethernet, fiber, LTE/3G/4G/5G, MPLS, microwave/radio, satellite, WiFi, or other). The Interface profile is
also where you specify the maximum upload and download speeds (in Mbps) of the ISPs connection. You can also
change whether the firewall monitors the path frequently or not; the firewall monitors link types appropriately by default.

tags.name: device-virtual-systems
tags.description:
Manages virtual systems. A virtual system (vsys) is an independent (virtual) firewall instance
that you can separately manage within a physical firewall. Each vsys can be an independent
firewall with its own security policy, interfaces, and administrators; a vsys enables you
to segment the administration of all policies, reporting, and visibility functions that
the firewall provides.
A virtual system configuration doesn't control firewall-level and network-level functions.
For each vsys, you can specify a collection of physical and logical firewall interfaces (including
VLANs and virtual wires) and security zones. If you require routing segmentation for each
vsys, you must create and assign additional virtual routers and assign interfaces, VLANs,
and virtual wires as needed.

tags.name: device-snmp-trap-server-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) trap sever profiles To alert you to system events or threats on your network. 
Monitored devices send SNMP traps to SNMP managers (trap servers).

tags.name: device-syslog-server-profiles
tags.description:
Manages Syslog server profiles that enable you to aggregate log data from different network devices such as routers, firewalls, and printers from 
different vendors into a central repository for archiving, analysis, and reporting. 
Palo Alto Networks firewalls can forward every type of log they generate to an external syslog server.

tags.name: device-email-server-profiles
tags.description:
Manages profiles to configure email alerts for System, Config, HIP Match, Correlation, Threat, WildFire Submission, and Traffic logs.
You can use separate profiles to send email notifications for each log type to a different server. To increase availability, 
define multiple servers (up to four) in a single profile.

tags.name: device-http-server-profiles
tags.description:
Manages profiles to forward logs to an HTTP(S) destination or integrates with HTTP-based services that expose an API. The profiles modify the URL, HTTP header, 
parameters, and the payload in the HTTP request. You can also use the HTTP server profile to access firewalls running the PAN-OS integrated 
User-ID agent and register one or more tags to a source or destination IP address on logs that a firewall generated.

tags.name: device-ldap-server-profiles
tags.description:
Manages an LDAP Server Profile to configure settings for the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) servers that authentication profiles reference.
You can use LDAP to authenticate end users who access your network resources (through GlobalProtect or Authentication Portal) and administrators defined 
locally on the firewall or Panorama.

tags.name: device-log-interface-setting
tags.description:
Manages configuration of IP addresses, netmasks, and LACP for log interfaces.
Palo Alto Networks recommends that you assign separate interfaces for log collection and Collector Group
communication to reduce traffic on the MGT interface

tags.name: panorama-scheduled-config-push-profiles
tags.description: Some Description

tags.name: panorama-snmp-trap-server-profiles
tags.description: Some description

tags.name: panorama-syslog-server-profiles
tags.description: Some description

tags.name: panorama-email-server-profiles
tags.description: Some description

tags.name: panorama-http-server-profiles
tags.description: Some description

tags.name: panorama-ldap-server-profiles
tags.description: Some description

tags.name: panorama-device-groups
tags.description:
Manages device groups. Device groups are comprised of firewalls and virtual systems you want to
manage as a group, such as the firewalls that manage a group of branch offices or individual
departments in a company. Panorama treats these groups as single units when applying policies.
Firewalls can belong to only one device group but, because virtual systems are distinct entities
in Panorama, you can assign virtual systems within a firewall to different device groups.

tags.name: panorama-templates
tags.description:
Manages templates. Templates are the basic building blocks you use to configure the Network
and Device tabs on Panorama. You can use templates to define interface and zone configurations,
to manage the server profiles for logging and syslog access, or to define VPN configurations.

tags.name: panorama-template-stacks
tags.description:
Manages template stacks, which give you the ability to layer multiple templates and create
a combined configuration. Template stacks simplify management because they allow you to define
a common base configuration for all devices attached to the template stack and they give you
the ability to layer templates to create a combined configuration.
